ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I came away from this course with the ability to read a decent amount of Literary Chinese.

I learned basic syntax, vocabulary, idioms, and reading strategies to aid my understanding of basic literary Chinese texts. I more have an understanding of many underlying meanings of Modern Chinese characters and sentence structures. Through memorization tasks, I have internalized aspects of literary Chineses form and structure.

This course provides a thorough introduction to Classical Chinese. From a purely technical standpoint, I learned to recognize (and in some cases, write) more traditional characters, and acquired a great many grammatical constructions used in literary texts. Our readings also yielded a better understanding of Chinese history and culture, e.g. the origin of certain chengyu.

I gained proficiency in reading and interpreting ancient texts in literary Chinese. I also had many insights relating to linguistics, ancient Chinese history, historiography, and early Chinese philosophy.

Familiarity with classical Chinese, working from a background in Mandarin Chinese fluency. The course developed skills ranging from grammatical and syntactic constructions to older vocabulary as well as exposure to the literary and philosophical dimensions of the Chinese textual tradition.
Knowledge and reading ability of literary Chinese

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This course does a good job at introducing you to a wide array of texts, grammar, and vocabulary that are mostly useful in reading other texts. It builds a very good foundation and strongly emphasizes simple and foundational grammar and vocabulary points while also maintaining a discussion on the culture of early China. However the way the homework is organized is really not conducive to helping you understand the texts or showing your understanding of the text. It would make more sense to have a translation homework after you have learned a text in class, but in this class we were expected to finish the translation before class, and then we had a short period of time after class where we could correct our translation. I find it cemented bad habits and misinterpretations more firmly for me to do the translation before class, but there was simply not enough time after class to wait and do it then. Another pitfall is that we almost never made it through the lessons during class in the last half of the semester, so we had to finish half of a lesson in the next class before we could start the new one. This meant that we were expected to translate and turn in a text when we hadn't even learned half of it yet.

The greatest strength of this course is the care that Dr. Lin puts into each lesson. Dr. Lin answered every question that I had in a thoughtful manner, and planned her assignments such that the coursework never felt like busy work. 

One way that the course could be improved is to post the slides related to important grammar patterns on Canvas. After the midterm, this would be particularly useful as there were no longer any grammar exercises to refer back to during review before the weekly quizzes. One example of this is the ObjSubVb pattern which did not have a corresponding grammar worksheet but was still on a weekly quiz and the final.
Great course. Perhaps we could look at more texts without punctuation and try to punctuate them before attempting to read  them?

One strength of the course was its emphasis on reading and translating passages on our own, as this was probably what I learned the most from.  
One weakness of the course is that we did not address in class some of the more unusual grammar structures we had to translate for homework, so I would have appreciated more breakdowns of particularly difficult phrases.

Strengths: Engaging instructor, insightful texts and manuscripts, applicability to other courses and practices I've undertaken 
Weaknesses: Some stress from high workload and regular assignments due

Good student engagement, interesting readings
Not enough time left for class discussion because quizzes were too long

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: If you are not required to take this class, I honestly wouldn't recommend it.
I would highly recommend this course to another student. Not only is the material highly engaging, but Dr. Lin is also a fantastic instructor to be teaching this course.
Yes! If you have a question take it!

I would strongly recommend this course, especially after taking other L5+ electives. My focus in studying Chinese is on modern usage of the language (especially for interpretation), and this course was still very interesting and helpful to me. Studying literary Chinese has helped me speak modern Chinese in a more elegant and native-like way, especially by integrating idioms and understanding the origins of grammatical patterns.

Great class! Professor is incredible and the material is very fun and interesting. Just note that the workload starts off very light for the first month or so, but at the end the translations due each class become much longer and take several hours to complete. That being said, the work is quite pleasant!

Yes, though specifically for those with an interest in pre-modern Chinese history and literature, whether for research purposes or to satisfy other intellectual curiosities. Course was well-designed to provide exposure to the building blocks of literary Chinese and a great confidence booster as we progressed from short tales to long narratives.
Yes; very interesting content and Dr. P is very kind

extras.title: CHNS 170 01/CHNS 570 01 - Intro to Literary Chinese I
